videos.title: ScHoolboy Q - Floating (2019)
videos.additional_info:
ScHoolboy Q - Floating (2019)
Schoolboy Q's music video for "Floating" features a dizzying, dreamlike journey through the streets of Los Angeles, with distorted visuals and rapid camera movements capturing a surreal sense of disconnection. The video mirrors the song's hazy, laid-back vibe, immersing viewers in a trippy, out-of-body experience. Directors: @jackbegert @davefree Prod Co: @ajrfilms / @topdawgent Producer: @ajrfilms @davefree @autumn_hymes @dangerookipawaa Label: @topdawgent Reps: @retone @keemtde @bigbtde @moosatde DOP: @christopher.c.ripley 1st AC: @themeganjohnsondp 2nd AC: @angelogentileiii Camera Utility: Brent Johnson B Camera: @silva_screen AD Team : @haitianev Production Design @fusinadesigns Production Assistant @marcodinero @justjream Editor : @neal_farmstrong @jackbegert Vfx: @thermonuclear.tv @neal_farmstrong Stylist: @dianne Casting: @millticketceo Co Star: @mackwop @smactheboss @Im.t.f @misterctoon @iamhwood

videos.title: Ken Carson - Fighting My Demons (2023)
videos.description: The music video for "Fighting My Demons" by Ken Carson, directed by Cole Bennett, was released in 2023 and features unique, glitchy visuals. The video presents a series of grainy, 3D footage that gives off the impression of being shot with night-vision goggles, offering a surreal viewing experience. It mainly showcases Ken Carson partying and performing his lyrics, creating a montage that aligns with the song's themes. The video's eerie and dark aesthetics were noted for drawing inspiration from the style of 1990s Japanese cinema, culminating in a profound, existential moment where Ken faces a haunting black void, adding depth and narrative to the visual experience.
videos.additional_info:
Ken Carson - Fighting My Demons (2023)
The music video for "Fighting My Demons" by Ken Carson, directed by Cole Bennett, was released in 2023 and features unique, glitchy visuals. The video presents a series of grainy, 3D footage that gives off the impression of being shot with night-vision goggles, offering a surreal viewing experience. It mainly showcases Ken Carson partying and performing his lyrics, creating a montage that aligns with the song's themes. The video's eerie and dark aesthetics were noted for drawing inspiration from the style of 1990s Japanese cinema, culminating in a profound, existential moment where Ken faces a haunting black void, adding depth and narrative to the visual experience.
Technique - Pass Through
Director - Cole Bennett
DOP - Franklin Ricart
Editor - Cole Bennett
Colorist - Loren White
Original Source - Link

videos.title: Aminé - Charmander (2021)
videos.description: In the 2021 music video "Charmander" by Aminé, the artist retreats to a secluded cabin in the woods, symbolizing a quest for peace and introspection away from the pressures of fame. The video is characterized by a warm, earthy color palette and natural light, capturing the tranquil beauty of the forest setting. The nostalgic reference to Pokémon through the title "Charmander" adds a whimsical contrast to the mature themes of self-discovery and isolation.
videos.additional_info:

videos.title: Audrey Nuna - Cellulite (2023)
videos.description: Audrey Nuna's "Cellulite" music video, directed by Zac Dov, is a vivid narrative of self-liberation and defiance, drawing inspiration from icons like the Pharcyde and Missy Elliott. The video visually represents Nuna's personal theme of overcoming constraints, symbolized by motifs of flying and motion, reflecting her introspective yet rebellious spirit. It's a cinematic portrayal of cutting out life's "toxic fat," aiming to resonate with viewers on a journey of spiritual unburdening.
videos.additional_info:

videos.description: Season 1. Episode 6. Eddie Horniman inherits a family estate, initially unaware its home to a drug empire run by a syndicate that has no plans to vacate. videos.alt_text: Elderbrook - Why Do We Shake In The Cold?
videos.title: Elderbrook - Why Do We Shake In The Cold? (2020)
videos.additional_info:
Elderbrook - Why Do We Shake In The Cold? (2020)
Delirium-induced fata morgana brings together two lone friends. Constantly trying to break through their bubbles, they seem stuck in ever repeating loops - Elderbrook's new video is a reminder of invisible everyday habbits and patterns that form our lives. Performers: Antonín Ničovský, Daniel Vitešník Director - Jára Moravec DoP - Filip Marek Executive Producer: Carla Mooney, Delwyn Mooney Producer - Mojaš Perović Edit: Katarina Gramatová Production Manager - Klára Plechsson 1AD - Kristýna Rousková 1AC - Jan “Hofajz” Hofmann 2AC - Richard Krejza Set dressing: Helena Liška, Václav Bejlek Props - Farid Beyzai, Martin Žerdík Ronin op. - Anton Endovshenko Drone op - Vojtěch Pollák Gaffer - Tomáš Volter Electrician - Roman Lety Jabůrek Costumes/MUP - Aneta Boháčová Catering - Lenka Egrtová Transport - Jan Salvet Production Company: Cardel Service Production Company: Bistro Films

videos.description: Dillon Francis, Good Times Ahead - LA On Acid (2023)
videos.additional_info:
Dillon Francis, Good Times Ahead - LA On Acid (2023)
A mesmerizing music video featuring a chaotic journey initiated by Diplo's spiked chicken nugget, showcasing wild camera angles, unusual characters, and intense visual effects set in a quirky vintage Chinese restaurant. Director Seaman's close collaboration with Francis ensures a deep connection with the song's rhythms and lyrics, bringing to life a vividly demented world that captivates viewers, with or without the influence of LSD.
Technique - Object Portal , Pass Through , Title Card , Typography
Director - Parker Seaman
DOP - Franklin Ricart
Editor - Jacob Ehrlich
Colorist - Josh Bohoskey
Original Source - Link
